title: Middle Distance
blurb: Capturing mid-range perspectives in layered abstraction, this work balances form and void to create a contemplative depth, reflecting Armstrong’s ongoing dialogue with distance as both physical and psychological. Framed dimensions: 33.5 × 43.5 × 3.5 cm.
artist_bio: Robert Armstrong’s abstract landscapes explore themes of distance, form, and spatial perception, drawing from Irish environments to create introspective, layered compositions. His work balances restraint with subtle emotional depth, inviting sustained viewer engagement through nuanced color and structure.

Robert Armstrong was born in 1953 in Gorey, Ireland, and lives and works in Dublin. He studied at the National College of Art & Design (NCAD), where he later served as Head of Painting from 2002 to 2018.

Armstrong has had solo exhibitions including “After Mountains, More Mountains” at Kevin Kavanagh Gallery, Dublin (2023). He has participated in recent group exhibitions at Galleri Bo Bjerggaard, Copenhagen (2024); Art Rotterdam (2024); and RHA Annual Exhibition, Dublin (2024).
View Full Artist Profile: https://www.532gallery.com/artists/118-robert-armstrong/

title: Lightsome Distance
blurb: This piece evokes a luminous expanse of abstract landscape, where subtle gradients and forms suggest ethereal horizons, drawing from Armstrong’s exploration of spatial lightness and emotional resonance in Irish-inspired terrains. Framed dimensions: 33.5 × 43.5 × 3.5 cm.
artist_bio: Robert Armstrong’s abstract landscapes explore themes of distance, form, and spatial perception, drawing from Irish environments to create introspective, layered compositions. title: Wood Anemone
blurb: Inspired by spring walks in Swedish and Irish natures, this painting uses spray paint and oils to capture the vivid whites and greens of anemones, detaching from source photos to form an immersive forest narrative that treats landscape as an extension of the self. Framed dimensions: 32.5 × 42.5 × 4 cm.
artist_bio: Cecilia Danell’s multidisciplinary practice merges painting, sculpture, film, and textiles, focusing on landscape psychology and materiality as extensions of the self. Her process-driven works detach from photographic sources to forge new narratives, capturing vibrant forest scenes and cropped details with spray paint and oils for immersive, sensory experiences.
Cecilia Danell was born in 1985 in Sweden and is based in Ireland. She holds degrees in fine art, with residencies at Monson Arts, USA (2024) and Ballinglen Arts Foundation, Ireland (2021).

Danell has had solo exhibitions including “Brush Lightly Through Fireweed Forests” at Kevin Kavanagh, Dublin (2022) and “A Stillness Expanded” at Claremorris Gallery, Ireland (2023). She has participated in recent group exhibitions at the 195th RHA Annual Exhibition, Dublin (2025); Salong Östergötland, Linköping Konsthall, Sweden (2025); and “What the Plants Know” at Galway International Arts Festival (2024).
View Full Artist Profile: https://www.532gallery.com/artists/120-cecilia-danell/

title: Bluebell Lane
blurb: Drawn from bluebell-filled paths, this vibrant scene employs layered colors to evoke the scale and depth of nature, inviting viewers into a snapshot of spring foliage where materiality and psychology converge in a process-driven exploration. Framed dimensions: 32.5 × 42.5 × 4 cm.
artist_bio: Cecilia Danell’s multidisciplinary practice merges painting, sculpture, film, and textiles, focusing on landscape psychology and materiality as extensions of the self. title: Evening
medium: Acrylic on 300 lb. paper, white frame
blurb: This watercolor captures the softening hues of dusk in a landscape vista, blending plein air observation with memory to evoke a sense of peaceful transition, positioning beauty as a subtle protest against environmental flux.
artist_bio: Lily Prince’s plein air-inspired works translate observational landscapes into personal expressions of universal significance, viewing beauty as a form of protest amid environmental and societal challenges. Combining direct perception, memory, and aspiration, her watercolor, gouache, and oil pastel pieces create fresh vistas that feel familiar yet surprising, drawing from terrains like the American West, Italy, and New York’s Hudson Valley.
Prince was born in 1962 and is based in New York and the Hudson Valley. She received her BFA from Rhode Island School of Design and her MFA from Bard College, with a residency at Skowhegan.

Prince has had solo exhibitions linked to residencies at Olana and BAU Institute, Italy. She has participated in recent group exhibitions at the New Museum, NY; Galerie Huit, Arles, France; and Draftsmen’s Congress at The New Museum.
View Full Artist Profile: https://www.532gallery.com/artists/75-lily-prince/

title: Morning
blurb: Depicting the fresh glow of dawn’s light on terrain, this piece translates direct perception into aspirational space, merging Italian, Irish, and American West influences for an uplifting narrative of renewal.

title: Cacti (Allerton Park Greenhouse)
medium: Watercolor on paper, mounted on panel
blurb: Bird’s-eye cacti cluster in lush detail, blending impressionistic snapshots with abstraction to evoke the sensual textures and sounds of greenhouse life.
artist_bio: Patrick Neal’s watercolor paintings are lush and teeming with life, depicting still lifes and landscapes from studio props, parks, and gardens. Viewed from bird’s-eye perspectives, his works activate edge-to-edge surfaces, blending impressionistic observation with abstraction to evoke sensual qualities and bodily discovery.

Patrick Neal was born in 1966 in Troy, NY, and is based in New York and Queens. He holds an MFA from Yale University and attended Yale Norfolk School of Art, the New York Studio School, and Skowhegan.

Neal has had solo exhibitions throughout New York. He has participated in recent group exhibitions supported by his 2018 NYFA Artist Fellow in Painting and Queens Art Fund New Work Grant, with works in private and public collections.
View Full Artist Profile: https://www.532gallery.com/artists/115-patrick-neal/

title: Cosmic Lotus Moth
medium: Archival pigment inks on cotton rag paper with salt crystals, gold leaf, and color pencil
blurb: Blending lotus blooms with moth forms in a starry cosmos, this work imagines fluid connections between earthly flora and celestial realms, inspired by 19th-century naturalists to fluctuate between microcosmic details and macroscopic wonders. Framed dimensions: 63.5 × 53.5 × 3.1 cm.
artist_bio: Christine Nguyen’s work draws on nature, science, and the cosmos, imagining fluid connections between ocean depths and outer space through an organic prism. Her practice, inspired by 19th-century naturalists like Ernst Haeckel and Anna Atkins, extracts curiosities from the natural world to create meditative, micro-macroscopic visions blending biology, philosophy, and mystery.

Nguyen was born in 1977 in Mountain View, California, and resides in Aurora, Colorado, and Long Beach, California. She received her BFA from California State University, Long Beach, and her MFA from the University of California, Irvine.

Nguyen has had solo exhibitions tied to residencies at Montello Foundation, NV, and Pacific Bonsai Museum, WA. She has participated in recent group exhibitions at the J. Paul Getty Museum and Armand Hammer Museum, with works in collections including the Getty Research Institute and Long Beach Museum of Art.
View Full Artist Profile: https://www.532gallery.com/artists/76-christine-nguyen/

title: Earth Gem
medium: Oil on porous matte gesso, wood frame
blurb: This installation-like painting evokes a crystalline gem from recycled materials, drawing on Riede’s dance-movement records to suggest geological strata and rebirth, like a phoenix emerging from earth’s layers. Framed dimensions: 104.6 × 79.2 × 4 cm.
artist_bio: Danielle Riede’s practice deconstructs painting traditions through site-specific installations using recycled materials, exploring themes of time, nature, and ephemerality. Her works, such as the “Ocean Womb” series, evoke geodes, glaciers, and biological forms, blending storytelling with visual and audio elements to inspire empathy for terrestrial and aquatic realms.

Riede was born in 1976 in Grand Junction, Colorado, and was raised in the US and Iceland. She received her BFA from the University of Virginia and her MFA in Painting from Virginia Commonwealth University, and studied with Daniel Buren at the Kunstakademie Düsseldorf.

Riede has had solo exhibitions including “Venus Walks on Pearls” at Künstlerloge, Ratingen, Germany. She has participated in recent group exhibitions in Mexico City, Athens, Berlin, and New York, with works in international museum collections.
View Full Artist Profile: https://www.532gallery.com/artists/77-danielle-riede/

blurb: Radiant hues mimic auroral lights in abstract form, using body-as-brush techniques to blend fall and spring motifs, exploring timelessness through glowing, strata-inspired compositions.

title: A Darker Star
blurb: This intimate oil blends shadowy gestures with luminous accents, exploring memory’s ambiguity through abstracted figuration, where a darker celestial form evokes transitory sensations in Copperwhite’s hypnotic palette.
artist_bio: In her paintings, Diana Copperwhite explores the relationship between colors, gestures, figuration, and representation, harmonizing different visual strategies on the canvas. Copperwhite amalgamates images from the internet, photographs, and real life, unifying these sources in paintings that critically assess the medium’s ability to represent images, sensations, and ideas.

Diana Copperwhite was born in 1969 in Limerick, Ireland, and lives and works in Dublin. She studied at the Limerick School of Art and Design, received a BA in painting at the National College of Art and Design, Dublin, and an MFA at the Winchester School of Art and Design, Barcelona.

Copperwhite has had solo exhibitions including “Reflections in a Darker Mirror” (2022–2023), “The Clock Struck Between Time” reviewed in Brooklyn Rail (2019), and “Depend on the Morning Sun” reviewed in Hyperallergic (2017). She has participated in recent group exhibitions at CAN Ibiza Art Fair (2025), CONTEXT Art Miami (2022), and “Anarene” (2023).
View Full Artist Profile: https://www.532gallery.com/artists/31-diana-copperwhite/

title: Dancers With Islands
blurb: Finger-painted dancers whirl amid island forms, capturing playful human gestures in a narrative scene that blends memory and invention, evoking joy through Parks’ rich, evocative surfaces. Framed dimensions: 23 × 30.5 cm.
artist_bio: John Alexander Parks’ finger-painted narratives explore human gestures and interactions through playful, putti-inspired scenes executed from memory. His works blend childish methods with mature themes, creating rich surfaces that evoke the stuff of memory and universal behaviors.

John A. Parks was born in 1952 in Leeds, England, and lives and works in New York. He received his MA in Painting from the Royal College of Art, London (1976), and BA in Fine Art from Hull College of Art (1973).

Parks has had solo exhibitions widely in the US and England over thirty years. He has participated in recent group exhibitions with works in collections like the Victoria and Albert Museum, London, and the Museum of the Rhode Island School of Design.
View Full Artist Profile: https://www.532gallery.com/artists/35-john-alexander-parks/

title: Trams and Beach
blurb: Trams glide past beachgoers in this whimsical composition, using childish techniques to explore grownup interactions, with vibrant colors and textures drawing from Parks’ putti-inspired series for humorous insight.

title: Afternoon
blurb: A serene yet charged afternoon vista incorporates theoretical contrasts, inviting reflection on first- and third-world divides through mixed-media subtlety and compelling visual dialogue.
artist_bio: Tanja Selzer’s paintings explore the boundaries of voyeuristic situations and their social consequences, confronting class issues, power dynamics, and contrasts between first- and third-world realities. Her work incorporates theoretical texts and compelling imagery, often invoking the contemporary art scene itself through mixed-media elements.
Selzer was born in 1970 in Idar-Oberstein, Germany, and lives and works in Berlin. She completed her studies at the University of Applied Sciences, Department of Design in Hamburg.

Selzer has had solo exhibitions internationally since 2005, including “Meet me in the trees” featured in a meer.com article (2014). She has participated in group exhibitions including Art Fair 21, Cologne (2008, Gesellschafter Art Award), with works in public and private collections worldwide.
View Full Artist Profile: https://www.532gallery.com/artists/41-tanja-selzer/

title: Pintura de Acción
blurb: An action-driven composition incorporates Afro-Cuban elements, evolving political symbols into abstract gestures that demand new interpretations of power, faith, and cultural contrasts.
artist_bio: José Vincench’s conceptual art addresses Cuban social life, religious backgrounds, and political perspectives, incorporating Afro-Cuban ritual elements distilled into graphic simplicity. Evolving toward minimalism and abstraction in response to 1980s political shifts, his works demand new readings of gods, commoners, hope, despair, faith, and mistrust.
Vincench was born in 1973 in Holguín, Cuba, and lives and works in Havana. He completed his art studies at Havana’s Instituto Superior de Arte (ISA).
View Full Artist Profile: https://www.532gallery.com/artists/32-jose-vincench/

title: Riotous Blossoms
blurb: This vibrant mixed-media piece bursts with symbolic flowers, confronting class divides and power dynamics through riotous contrasts, demanding a reexamination of hope amid despair in Pétion’s signature blend of first- and third-world imagery.
artist_bio: Jean-Guerly Pétion uses symbols and imageries suggesting extremes of differences, with paintings confronting first- and third-world class issues via theoretical texts and power depictions in assemblage and mixed-media. His work demands new readings of gods and commoners, hope and despair, faith and mistrust.
Pétion was born in Haiti and lives and works in Los Angeles, California. He holds a BFA from the Kansas City Art Institute and an MFA from CalArts.
View Full Artist Profile: https://www.532gallery.com/artists/36-jean-guerly-petion/

title: Untitled (London)
blurb: This mixed-media piece layers graffiti text and dripping colors on cardboard, crowning hunger motifs with a bacon-fish-poultry throne, provocatively blending urban decay with divine absurdity to question consumption and isolation in city life.
artist_bio: Since Fulvio Gonella's teenage years, he has been enthralled by the realm of art brut, a domain where diverse perspectives craft distinct realities. His current paintings combine the tenets of this radical artistic movement with a highly gestural style reflective of street art, graffiti and graphic design, and folkloric imagery. The results combine ferocious visual energy with a whimsical, mysterious sensibility redolent with evocative imagery drawn from an abundant imagination.

Traditionally, art brut artists create their works for their own use as a kind of private theatre, motivated by an endogenous psychodramatic drive. Gonella takes the dynamic a step further in that his works are created for the use of the viewer; “Whispers in the Twilight” comprises a public theatre of sorts.

The first element in this visual carnival is the nearly aggressively crude and gestural signifiers that Gonella constructs. Using a salmagundi of paints and colors, liquids, crayons, oil stick, enamel and found materials — literally mixed media — Gonella populates his canvases with sketched-out outlines of stick figures with primitive faces, while objects are depicted in assertively flat renditions.

title: Blossoms
blurb: Fluid blossoms entwine in psychological color-spaces, exploring viscera-brain links through sensuous pinks and blues, suggesting bodily tangles and emotional metaphors.
artist_bio: Ian Hughes’ paintings probe the psychological and emotional links between brain and viscera, with naturalistic forms shape-shifting over flat color-spaces. Fluid, intertwining elements suggest bodily presence and shifting associations, seducing viewers through sensuous textures and a palette of pinks, yellows, and blues modulated by whites and blacks.
Hughes lives and works in New York City. He received his BA from Yale College (1981) and his MFA from Columbia University School of Art (1984).

Hughes has had solo exhibitions including a booth at UNTITLED: Miami (2012). He has participated in group exhibitions at The Drawing Center (Selections 31), White Columns (1991), and Artists’ Space (1998, celebrating its 25th Anniversary).
View Full Artist Profile: https://www.532gallery.com/artists/34-ian-hughes/

blurb: A vertical surge of intertwining forms waves over abstract fields, modulating textures to evoke stress and shifting associations in Hughes’ “Twisted Figures” vein.

title: Candy Girl
blurb: A candy-hued figure pops with playful energy, fusing Mongolian motifs with consumerist whimsy to explore identity in a vibrant, graphic narrative.
artist_bio: Zayasaikhan Sambuu’s vibrant paintings fuse pop culture with Mongolian traditions, using candy-like colors and playful motifs to explore themes of consumerism, identity, and modern life. His works balance bold graphic elements with subtle cultural commentary, creating energetic compositions that invite viewers to reflect on global influences through a whimsical lens.
Zayasaikhan Sambuu was born in 1975 in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia, and lives and works there. He received his education at the Mongolian University of Arts and Culture.

title: Candy Girl 2
blurb: Sequel to the series, this piece layers sweet colors and bold forms, commenting on cultural contrasts through Sambuu’s signature pop-traditional blend.
artist_bio: Zayasaikhan Sambuu’s vibrant paintings fuse pop culture with Mongolian traditions, using candy-like colors and playful motifs to explore themes of consumerism, identity, and modern life. His works balance bold graphic elements with subtle cultural commentary, creating energetic compositions that invite viewers to reflect on global influences through a whimsical lens.
Zayasaikhan Sambuu was born in 1975 in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia, and lives and works there. He received his education at the Mongolian University of Arts and Culture.

title: Sweet on You
blurb: Sugary tones and affectionate motifs entwine, inviting reflection on modern sweetness amid global influences, in Sambuu’s energetic style.
artist_bio: Zayasaikhan Sambuu’s vibrant paintings fuse pop culture with Mongolian traditions, using candy-like colors and playful motifs to explore themes of consumerism, identity, and modern life. His works balance bold graphic elements with subtle cultural commentary, creating energetic compositions that invite viewers to reflect on global influences through a whimsical lens.
Zayasaikhan Sambuu was born in 1975 in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia, and lives and works there. He received his education at the Mongolian University of Arts and Culture.

title: Super Pig
blurb: This playful yet pointed painting reimagines a porcine superhero through Ogilvie’s lens on unreliable narrators, blending toy-like whimsy with cultural critique to explore contemporary absurdity and power dynamics.
artist_bio: Morgan Ogilvie’s paintings delve into the “unreliable” female narrator, weaving allusions to contemporary culture through whimsical, narrative-driven compositions that blend protest, prophecy, and play. Her works often feature bizarre, toy-like soldiers and surreal scenarios, inviting viewers to unpack layers of social commentary with humor and invention.
Ogilvie was born in 1992 and lives and works in Nashville, TN. She received her MFA from the California Institute of the Arts (CalArts) in 2020 and attended a residency at Vermont Studio Center.

Ogilvie has had solo exhibitions including “Secure Destruction You Can Trust” at the Frist Art Museum, Nashville, TN, and her first solo at Hutcheson Gallery, David Lipscomb. She has participated in recent group exhibitions at Zeitgeist Gallery, Nashville (2022); MAK Center, Los Angeles; and Imagine Entertainment, with features in Artforum.com and Hyperallergic.
View Full Artist Profile: https://www.532gallery.com/artists/123-morgan-ogilvie/
